user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketShutdown_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketShutdown_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_SocketShutdownMode_t Mode)
{
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *conn_impl;
    int32                           return_code;
    int                             how;

    conn_impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    /* Note that when called via the shared layer,
     * the "Mode" arg has already been checked/validated. */
    if (Mode == OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READ)
    {
        how = SHUT_RD;
    }
    else if (Mode == OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_WRITE)
    {
        how = SHUT_WR;
    }
    else
    {
        how = SHUT_RDWR;
    }

    if (shutdown(conn_impl->fd, how) == 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketShutdown_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
extern OS_impl_file_internal_record_t OS_impl_filehandle_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
...
typedef enum
{
    OS_SocketShutdownMode_NONE           = 0, /**< @brief Reserved value, no effect */
    OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READ      = 1, /**< @brief Disable future reading */
    OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_WRITE     = 2, /**< @brief Disable future writing */
    OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READWRITE = 3  /**< @brief Disable future reading or writing */
} OS_SocketShutdownMode_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragments require investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8. Reasons:
- The function parameters are 'const OS_object_token_t *token' and 'OS_SocketShutdownMode_t Mode'. Neither parameter is assigned to or modified anywhere in the function: Mode is only compared (not assigned) and token is only dereferenced/used to obtain the table index.
- The macro invocation OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token) expands to use the address of the token value (&(*token)), which effectively yields the original token pointer; this does not modify the parameter itself.
- The helper OS_ObjectIndexFromToken takes a const pointer and only reads token->obj_idx (no modification).
- conn_impl is a local variable that receives a pointer into OS_impl_filehandle_table; assigning to conn_impl does not modify the function parameters.
- The const qualifier on the token parameter prevents modifying the pointed-to object via that pointer within this function.
Given the above, there are no assignments or operations that modify the value of either function parameter or the pointer itself, so no fragments violate Rule 17.8.
